title: Gwyneth Paltrow tells how her new husband lured her back to TV in The Politician
text:
Gwyneth Paltrow caused a storm of publicity a couple of years ago when she declared she’d retired from acting in favour of running her controversial lifestyle website Goop.

‘I’m not focused on full-time acting right now,’ she told an American TV interviewer in 2017. ‘I love running my business, we’re growing so fast.’

In another interview she confessed, ‘I really liked acting, but at a certain point it started feeling frustrating,’ before admitting she felt she had been ‘masquerading as an actor’ all along.

Apart from her recurring role as prissy Pepper Potts in the Avengers films, she hadn’t been seen on screen for years.

And yet here she is on television playing Georgina Hobart, the free-spirited mother of an aspiring teenaged politician in black comedy The Politician, created by Ryan Murphy with whom she worked a few years ago on Glee.

Gwyneth Paltrow, pictured, caused a storm of publicity a couple of years ago when she declared she’d retired from acting in favour of running her controversial lifestyle website Goop. But now she is back on screen in Netflix's Politician, written by husband Brad Falchuk

But it involves Ryan’s frequent professional partner Brad Falchuk, the writer-director-producer who is in fact Gwyneth’s new husband.

‘I did it because I was sleeping with the writer!’ she laughs.

But it was indeed her relationship with Brad that got her to sign up.

‘Brad was writing the show and he kept telling me I was inspiring the part.

'Then he said, more seriously, “I’m writing this for you.” I told him I couldn’t do it because I was working full-time on Goop, and that there was no way I could take time out to do a TV show.

'So he suggested not making it too big a part. I said, “OK.”’

Which was when Ryan Murphy, the TV writer behind such TV hits as Glee, American Horror Story and Nip/Tuck, stepped in.

‘He called me and said that he really wanted me to do it. So I read it and I thought it was prescient, a really interesting comment on where we are right now in our society in America.

'Then they said they would try to make the work fit in around my job, so lo and behold, I’m in a TV show.’

Gwyneth Paltrow plays Georgina Hobart, the free-spirited mother of an aspiring teenaged politician in black comedy The Politician, opposite Ben Platt as Payton Hobart (pictured)

And what a TV show.

The Politician is the slyly satirical tale of Payton Hobart (Ben Platt), a hyper-intelligent but emotionally vacuous rich kid who’s known since the age of seven that he’s destined to become President of the United States.

The first rung on the ladder is running for Student Body President at his exclusive high school in wealthy Santa Barbara, California.

To do this, and secure the spot at Harvard that will continue his trajectory, Payton will have to outwit his ruthless classmates without sacrificing his carefully crafted image.

When his rival – handsome, likeable River (David Corenswet) – gallops past him in the popularity polls, Payton decides to make himself seem more attractive by selecting someone ‘undeniably real’ as a running mate, the sweet but sick Infinity Jackson (Zoey Deutch).

It’s a hilarious but terrifyingly accurate caricature of both the American political and education systems.

The last theme is especially timely in view of the recent scandal in which a number of rich Los Angeles parents, including Desperate Housewives’ Felicity Huffman, were found to have bribed people to secure their children a place at their preferred college.

‘The show does a really interesting job of examining white privilege,’ says Gwyneth, 47.

It was indeed her relationship with husband Brad Falchuk - a writer-director-producer - that encouraged Gwyneth to sign up to The Politician. Pictured, the couple last week

‘Rich people have always had an unfair advantage over less privileged people, and Brad feels very personally about how wrong that is.

'Just as an example, he came up with a storyline where my character paid for my kids to get into college, well before the scandal broke.

'So it was fascinating he’d been thinking about the responsibility of people of privilege.

'What is the responsibility, where does the line get drawn and where does it stop?’

She has greatly enjoyed working with her on-screen son, played by 26-year-old Ben Platt of Dear Evan Hansen and Pitch Perfect fame, who’s also an executive producer on the series.

‘He’s an incredibly driven person. He wanted to see every detail of everything, and he really threw himself into it.

'It’s great to see a young person who has that much conviction.’

Back at home, her real-life children Apple and Moses are now in their teens.

‘Which means I’m an old woman!’ she laughs.

‘I love having kids this age. I have genuinely adored every stage of parenting through all the different ages, it’s been the most rewarding – sometimes the most challenging – thing ever.

'I have a 13-year-old and a 15-year-old, and I’m so looking forward to having adult children.’

Gwyneth snapped this photo of ex-husband Chris Martin (left) with husband Brad Falchuk

It’s now five years since she and Coldplay singer Chris Martin infamously announced their split as ‘conscious uncoupling’, and she says, as far as she can see, their children are doing fine with the change in their lives.

‘They’ve managed to come through the divorce pretty OK – although I’m sure I’ve messed them up in other ways! My ex-husband and I called what we did “uncoupling” because we wanted to do it in a way that’d be the least traumatic for the children.

'The “conscious” part was about trying to do it in a way that was maybe different to how other people had.

‘It took a lot of work but it really paid off because Chris and I are still very close.

'We remain a family even though we’re not a couple – the kids appreciate that we’re still a family too.

'I was very lucky that my ex-husband and I wanted to stay close.

'We’re still close friends, and it’s because of that we’ve been able to move through our lives with other partners and feel that we’re adding to the family, instead of having it become divisive or difficult.

'I recognise it’s unusual, but I feel proud we’ve been able to do it.’

Gwyneth revealed her lifestyle brand Goop which is valued at around £200 million, has 250 employees. Pictured, the actress at the Emmy awards in Los Angeles last month

While Chris has gone on to long-term romances with actresses Jennifer Lawrence and Dakota Johnson, Gwyneth almost immediately began dating Brad, whom she married in the Hamptons last September, although they didn’t move in together until quite recently.

‘First I uncoupled, then I coupled!’ she laughs.

‘We decided for the first year to keep our separate residences and make the transition for the kids a bit more gentle. It’s worked out very well.

'We’ve finally moved in together. Of course there are always complications, but it’s going pretty well.’

Also going pretty well is Goop, which despite some very negative press is a thriving lifestyle brand valued at about £200 million.

‘We have 250 employees, 80 per cent women,’ she says.

‘When I started I had no idea what I was doing, and I didn’t imagine it’d become what it has.

'I can be a demanding boss as I’m a perfectionist and I don’t like it when we make the same mistakes more than once.

'But a work environment needs to feel collaborative, creative and kind, and the work/life balance needs to be good, particularly because we have so many working mothers here.’

She’s been thinking a lot about the work environment since the start of the #MeToo movement, another feature of modern life she helped pioneer by being among the first actresses to publicly accuse Harvey Weinstein of sexual harassment.

‘I was honoured to play a small part,’ she says.

‘I was ready to tell my story and support other women telling theirs.

'It was the right time. I wasn’t sure anything would change because it never had, but society and the world were ready for a new movement.’

So, Gwyneth Paltrow the politician? ‘God, no!’ she shudders.

‘Yes, we’re in a very polarised moment, and nobody’s listening to anybody else and it’s causing a lot of pain. But no, I’ll never run for office.’

The Politician is on Netflix now.
description: Actress Gwyneth Paltrow , 47, stars as Georgina Hobart in Netflix's The Politician. The mother-of-two told how her husband, Brad Falchuk, wrote the show with her in mind.
